Taku Jack,
On 8/18/2017 8:53 AM, Jack Bowers wrote: Taku ni Mille,
Thanks very much for your response!
Regarding the Codex, as you said, it is really unfortunate that Tisu didn't get to see it. I will of course take pictures and send them to him and you whenever I do get to see it for sure.
I've been thinking that the codexes would be a great possible theme around which to develop new Mixtec materials... Creating written descriptions of their contents meaning and history would be a great thing to do in Mixtec.
(I'll eventually come back with a more concrete ideas for this)..
Now for the questions:
So I've been glossing L155 today "Sa'va tsi Lochi" and I have some questions from that and maybe a few other random ones:
kusii ini In the booklet L155 there is a sentence:
Nako'on sa'va, kunkusii inuu Ooops! I didnꞌt see this. You wil write one "u" only.
"let's go frog, you'll be happy" (You will rejoice, you will enjoy (the party)), take pleasure in) "Vayamos rana, te vas a gozar."
If I am not wrong there are other verbs that have "ini" as part and the 2sg.inf is usually written as: "inu" > So why is this last part not written with just one "u" > "inu"? Because this is a mistake. I am glad youꞌve seen this.
..tiyachi chi'i tsino
Could you help me make sense of this sentence, particularly the bold part? Tisu's glosses are below but it doesn't make sense to me.
Tsa'a ñaa , kue sa'va yee vichi , tiyachi chi'i tsino
" Because of that frogs today have (are) (very flat) (?)" Lit.
Por eso las ranas hoy en día son muy planas como las conocemos.
Es por eso que hoy en día vemos que las ranas son planas.
Tisu's glosses: tiyachi chi'i = very flat I am not sure what chiꞌi means, but as I know no one in the village use chiꞌi to say "very" The translations above were done by a native speaker of Mixtec who told the story. tsino = we see (inclusive)
kuni 'to want' In which context? There are two "kuni"; the incompletive form of " tsini " to want and " kuni ", the basic form of to know or to see.
For example, " Kuni yu kuni yu nixi nani chaa ka . ".
I want to know what is the name of that man.
I want quiero
know saber
I yo
" Kuni yu ntakuaꞌa tatsaꞌvi Stoꞌo Nchuxi ".
I want to give thanks God.
God
" kunkuꞌun yu nuu ñuꞌú paa yu , takua kunu nixi tsani ra tsichi . "
( "tava" variant of "takua")
I am going to my fatherꞌs piece of land to know how he plough the soil. I am going to my fatherꞌs piece of land to see how he plough the soil.
land
I will go I'm going
So you will need to know the context.
In booklet L155 there is a sentence:
Nikunuu lochi ka ...
" the vulcher wanted.. After some time, the vulture.... Después de un rato, el zopilote (buitre).... "
In my verb tables I did with Tisu, 'to want' is one of the verbs we did all forms for and for the incompletive form of 3sg.inf. (although I am aware that he does have certain areas that varies from what is written in the books)
I would have expected "nikunia".. "ni‑" = completive; "kuni‑" = to want; "‑a" ‑ 3sg.inf. "nikunia" is one verb and "nikunuu" is another verb.
> Is this a variant? or a synonym? > Is "nikunia" wrong? > Or is there something else going on?
Nisana nui
In L155:
Cha nisana nui nto'i ntaki'an inka nto'o ña iin yachi xiin nto'i
" and he forgot his basket and picked up another one nearby Pero él se equivocó él de tenate, y agarró otro tenate que estaba cerca del tenate de él. "
Whereas 'forget' is in other documents and in my data is "sana ini", in this context it appears to be "sana nuu"
> is that right? See above.
Tatsa'vi nchu'a ni!! Tatsaꞌvi meu .
Na kaꞌan ko inka chaꞌncha . ( Thank you. Letꞌs talk in another ocassion. ) Na Millie Jack PS ‑ Next week I leave for a congress. I will come back on the 26, but I will join the basic writerꞌs workshop for indigenous people, since there will be three Mixtec friends attending the workshop. My colleague and I will be helping them during the workshop, since they are beginners. So for the next three weeks I wonꞌt be available. Sorry! The last day of the workshop will be on Friday, Sept. 8. On September 9 or 10 I will be driving to the village. So remember I wonꞌt have regular internet.
The Basic Writerꞌs Workshop for indigenous people is taught every year for three weeks. It would be nice if Tisu make plans to attend this workshop when he comes to visit his family.
